msgSnippet: Joshua is correct. Though the command java junit.textui.TestRunner your.Class  filename  helps us to create test reults in a file, we need to have a uniform

Subject: RE: [junit] Re: is there any easy way to write the test results i n a file 
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
In-Reply-To: <20010306171059.49229.qmail@...>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
From: balakrishnan sengodan <bsengodan@...>

Joshua is correct. Though the command "java
junit.textui.TestRunner your.Class > filename " helps
us to create test reults in a file, we need to have a
uniform way to store test results for future use in
any matured development process.
Regards

--- Joshua Levy <joshualevy@...> wrote:
> 
> --- Kevin Bourrillion <kevinb@...> wrote:
> > Yes. 
> >     java junit.textui.TestRunner your.Class >
> filename
> >  
> > PS. If you were looking for a more specific
> answer... just ask a more
> > specific question!  :-)
> 
> I'll ask the more specific question:
>   I'm often expecting a complex text result for a
> test case.
>   I would like these "right answers" stored in a
> text file,
>   rather than in the source code of the junit test
> case.  I
>   suspect that adding a new method of the form
>   assertEquals(File expected, String result) 
>   would be very useful.  Has anyone done this, or
> something like 
>   this?  An even cooler way to do this (if possible)
> would
>   be a method like assertEqualsFile(String result),
> where the
>   method would determine the file name by concating
> the TestCase
>   name and the test method name.  Any thoughts on
> this?
> 
> Also, it would be nice if the javadoc generated
> documentation
> for junit where on line at the www.junit.org site. 
> (Or did I
> just miss them?)
> 
> Joshua  
> 
> __________________________________________________

>
